guild.description_html: A place to discuss ANY opinion, regardless of popularity, controversy, topic, etc. Please be respectful.
guild.name: ChangeMyView

post.title: Change my view: Toxic content is important even if it isn't enjoyable because it keeps away people who cant cope with that stuff

body:
I don't think it's _good_, but I do think it's inevitable. If we keep too many people away, this site will either die off, failing to attract a big enough user base, or end up like voat, with no content that isn't how it isn't Reddit.

_BUT_, there's no way to ban toxic content without ending up just like Reddit, so we have to deal with it. It's impossible to endorse free speech while censoring certain content.

Posting toxic content is bad, but allowing people to post toxic content is good.
body_html:
I don't think it's good, but I do think it's inevitable. If we keep too many people away, this site will either die off, failing to attract a big enough user base, or end up like voat, with no content that isn't how it isn't Reddit.

BUT, there's no way to ban toxic content without ending up just like Reddit, so we have to deal with it. It's impossible to endorse free speech while censoring certain content.

Posting toxic content is bad, but allowing people to post toxic content is good.

post.title: Change my view: Toxic content is important even if it isn't enjoyable because it keeps away people who cant cope with that stuff

body:
That's a respectable opinion, but I think in order for this site to last (both in terms of income, and content), it needs a bunch of uninteresting people, hell, I'm not even very interesting myself. 

If this place is going to be able to replace Reddit, it needs a space for people who only browse hobby subs, that doesn't have a bunch of trash to sift through.

We do agree that we still need a place where we allow people to post that trash though.

post.title: Change my view: Toxic content is important even if it isn't enjoyable because it keeps away people who cant cope with that stuff

body: I honestly think that keeping ruqqus a super closed off community of only people who want to deal with far right stuff is a bad move. Ruqqus can't really have much of an impact if it doesn't reach a wider audience. I'm not saying for the site to censor itself, because that would defeat the point. What I am saying is for ruqqus to open up to not be hostile towards those who don't want to deal with alt right garbage. And I think if we grow larger, we can have enough practical conversation that it will just drown out the garbage, without any censorship of opinions. Sorry if this post is kind of rambly.
body_html: I honestly think that keeping ruqqus a super closed off community of only people who want to deal with far right stuff is a bad move. What I am saying is for ruqqus to open up to not be hostile towards those who don't want to deal with alt right garbage. And I think if we grow larger, we can have enough practical conversation that it will just drown out the garbage, without any censorship of opinions. Sorry if this post is kind of rambly.

body:
4chan does this all the time... "let's post some gore to scare off the ~~newfags~~ newbies!" 

I do think having a thick skin is a *moral* quality of a human being, but I think newbies should be selected based on the likelihood they contribute, not on how sensitive they are.

4chan does this all the time... "let's post some gore to scare off the newfags newbies!"

I do think having a thick skin is a moral quality of a human being, but I think newbies should be selected based on the likelihood they contribute, not on how sensitive they are.

post.title: Change my view: Toxic content is important even if it isn't enjoyable because it keeps away people who cant cope with that stuff

body:
In the beginning, they believe their ideas are immune to open discourse.  When they find out how much the world actually disagrees with them, they become disillusioned and spiteful.  Then they leave.   Most people cannot change their opinions, it hurts too much.

They actually *do* prefer censorship,  they just don't like to admit it.

They actually do prefer censorship, they just don't like to admit it.

post.title: Change my view: Toxic content is important even if it isn't enjoyable because it keeps away people who cant cope with that stuff

body:
I disagree, I don't think reddit is what it is because it doesn't allow toxic content. There is plenty of toxic content on reddit, especially the leftist kind.
Reddit's problem is selling out to advertisers and China. They are pushing a narrative and removing posts that go against that narrative, some of those posts just happen to be toxic.
In my opinion censoring toxic content is fine as long as it's done fairly, not favoring one side over another.
body_html: I disagree, I don't think reddit is what it is because it doesn't allow toxic content. There is plenty of toxic content on reddit, especially the leftist kind. Reddit's problem is selling out to advertisers and China. They are pushing a narrative and removing posts that go against that narrative, some of those posts just happen to be toxic. In my opinion censoring toxic content is fine as long as it's done fairly, not favoring one side over another.

post.title: Change my view: Toxic content is important even if it isn't enjoyable because it keeps away people who cant cope with that stuff

body:
That depends on the definition of "toxic".  Differing opinions, absolutely yes.  Deliberately hurtful, that depends on context.

I'm reminded of the Coddling of the American Mind book that got play several years ago.  Mental Health requires a mental immune system much like physical health where "coping mechanisms" are the white blood cells.  In recent years, there has been an unprecedented rise in youth self harm and general mental disorders.

I believe this can be attributed to the "deplatforming" and echo chambering of any and all discussions.  We are seeing younger generations experiencing "mental asthma attacks" because they are not being exposed to external allergens.


https://londonreal.tv/jonathan-haidt/
body_html:
That depends on the definition of "toxic". Differing opinions, absolutely yes. Deliberately hurtful, that depends on context.

I'm reminded of the Coddling of the American Mind book that got play several years ago. Mental Health requires a mental immune system much like physical health where "coping mechanisms" are the white blood cells. In recent years, there has been an unprecedented rise in youth self harm and general mental disorders.

I believe this can be attributed to the "deplatforming" and echo chambering of any and all discussions. We are seeing younger generations experiencing "mental asthma attacks" because they are not being exposed to external allergens.

https://londonreal.tv/jonathan-haidt/

guild.description: A place to discuss ANY opinion, regardless of popularity, controversy, topic, etc. Please be respectful.
guild.description_html: A place to discuss ANY opinion, regardless of popularity, controversy, topic, etc. Please be respectful.
guild.name: ChangeMyView

post.title: Change my view: Toxic content is important even if it isn't enjoyable because it keeps away people who cant cope with that stuff

body:
I've had a guild for over a month and have received **1** submission from a member (a meme) and maybe **2** entire comments on content I've posted. I currently have 35 members and not  one of them bothers to participate. 

I posted a meme in my guild this morning. I laughed when I saw it, though it was one of those snort laughs when someone tells a sexist joke, but it's really funny, even though it shouldn't be and you're ashamed of yourself but you can't help your laugh. 

I've gotten 4 replies to it, 3 of them stating they found it offensive. But hey, they're posting and participating. I don't know if I should high five myself or hang my head in shame. People are hard wired to pay attention to things that are offensive, upsetting and controversial. We are hard-wired to want to do more of the same thing when we get attention. It's a viscous cycle. The news media knows this, which is why they constantly over-dramatize things and try to rile us up. 

It's not about keeping people away. It's about getting people to participate. The entire point of these sites is for people to say something. If all you do is scroll and hit up-down-vote, you're not contributing to the community, and the community will die. I came on before the R/ purge and the number of guilds that been abandoned by their creators was astounding. They were actually asking for mods to step up to take control of them. Why? Because there weren't enough people participating. It's simple math.
body_html:
I've had a guild for over a month and have received 1 submission from a member (a meme) and maybe 2 entire comments on content I've posted. I currently have 35 members and not one of them bothers to participate.

I posted a meme in my guild this morning. I laughed when I saw it, though it was one of those snort laughs when someone tells a sexist joke, but it's really funny, even though it shouldn't be and you're ashamed of yourself but you can't help your laugh.

I've gotten 4 replies to it, 3 of them stating they found it offensive. But hey, they're posting and participating. I don't know if I should high five myself or hang my head in shame. People are hard wired to pay attention to things that are offensive, upsetting and controversial. We are hard-wired to want to do more of the same thing when we get attention. It's a viscous cycle. The news media knows this, which is why they constantly over-dramatize things and try to rile us up.

It's not about keeping people away. It's about getting people to participate. The entire point of these sites is for people to say something. If all you do is scroll and hit up-down-vote, you're not contributing to the community, and the community will die. I came on before the R/ purge and the number of guilds that been abandoned by their creators was astounding. They were actually asking for mods to step up to take control of them. Why? Because there weren't enough people participating. It's simple math.

parent.body:
In the beginning, they believe their ideas are immune to open discourse.  When they find out how much the world actually disagrees with them, they become disillusioned and spiteful.  Then they leave.   Most people cannot change their opinions, it hurts too much.

They actually *do* prefer censorship,  they just don't like to admit it.

In the beginning, they believe their ideas are immune to open discourse. When they find out how much the world actually disagrees with them, they become disillusioned and spiteful. Then they leave. Most people cannot change their opinions, it hurts too much.

They actually do prefer censorship, they just don't like to admit it.

post.title: Change my view: Toxic content is important even if it isn't enjoyable because it keeps away people who cant cope with that stuff

body: The push for more content is more focused on  hobby subs, which used to be the life blood of Reddit. A lot of hobby guilds here will go multiple days between posts. I think garbage in-jokes are more of a result of how big an online community becomes. 8-ish years ago, /r/gaming was garbage, but you could go to the subreddit of an individual game you like, and find good discussions there.

I think garbage in-jokes are more of a result of how big an online community becomes. 8-ish years ago, /r/gaming was garbage, but you could go to the subreddit of an individual game you like, and find good discussions there.

post.title: Change my view: Toxic content is important even if it isn't enjoyable because it keeps away people who cant cope with that stuff

body:
While I agree with you to a certain extent (keeping people who can't cope with this stuff away), we're treading a thin line of becoming an echo chamber ourselves. When people show up on a bad day and the front page/trending is all "toxic content", most people will be put off by it, not just the "can't cope" people you're talking about. Heck, from some of the comments and replies I've seen on Reddit whenever someone brings up Ruqqus, some of them already call us Voat 2.0. And before you write all those people off as part of the "can't cope" crowd, remember that a huge chunk of Ruqqus' userbase came from Reddit (and not all of them lean right/far-right)

I truly believe Ruqqus has potential, but like others have already mentioned many times already, if we scare too many people away, this place will die.
body_html:
While I agree with you to a certain extent (keeping people who can't cope with this stuff away), we're treading a thin line of becoming an echo chamber ourselves. When people show up on a bad day and the front page/trending is all "toxic content", most people will be put off by it, not just the "can't cope" people you're talking about. Heck, from some of the comments and replies I've seen on Reddit whenever someone brings up Ruqqus, some of them already call us Voat 2.0. And before you write all those people off as part of the "can't cope" crowd, remember that a huge chunk of Ruqqus' userbase came from Reddit (and not all of them lean right/far-right)

I truly believe Ruqqus has potential, but like others have already mentioned many times already, if we scare too many people away, this place will die.

Other platforms like ruq will grow no worries. Reddit will be digg 2.0 and those communities will be found a plenty. No need for hand wringing and crystal balling
